qas.question: How many mass extinctions have happened since Life began on Earth?
When was the period where the majority of multicellular phyla first appeared?

answers.text: rainforest collapse led to a great loss of plant and animal life.

qas.question: When was the Permian–Triassic extinction event?
How long did vertebrate recovery take?
How many mass extinctions have happened since the Cambrian?
When was the period where the majority of biodiversity appeared?

plausible_answers.text: rainforest collapse led to a great loss of plant and animal life

qas.question: What happened in the several minor events?
When was the first Cambrian extinction event?
How long did rainforest recovery take?

context: Since life began on Earth, <a0_0><b5_0>five major mass extinctions<b5_0/><a0_0/> and several minor events have led to large and sudden drops in biodiversity. The Phanerozoic eon (the last 540 million years) marked a rapid growth in biodiversity via <a1_0><b6_0>the Cambrian explosion<b6_0/><a1_0/>—a period during which the majority of multicellular phyla first appeared. The next 400 million years included repeated, massive biodiversity losses classified as mass extinction events. In the Carboniferous, <a2_0><b7_0>rainforest collapse led to a great loss of plant and animal life<b7_0/>.<a2_0/> The Permian–Triassic extinction event, <a3_0><b8_0>251 million years ago<b8_0/><a3_0/>, was the worst; vertebrate recovery took <a4_0><b9_0>30 million years<b9_0/><a4_0/>. The most recent, the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event, occurred 65 million years ago and has often attracted more attention than others because it resulted in the extinction of the dinosaurs.
